results.title: Aboriginal dance: cultural reflections (A)
results.brief_description: The environment has played an important role in Aboriginal society for thousands of years. The You Yangs (a big mountain in the middle of a plane) are a granite outcrop near Geelong that in the past has provided a food and water supply for the Wathaurong people. Art, music and dance provide an important outlet for the expression of culture, illustrated in this short documentary through the painting “Hunting and ceremonial grounds in the You Yangs” by Stan Couzens and in the performance of the Je Be Weng Dancers (Alan Browning, Casey Browning, Gordon Hollander, Christal Raymond). The Dancers perform 3 pieces - The Creation Dance, The Warrior Dance and The Celebration Dance. The significance of their body decoration and the movements depicted are also explained.

results.title: Aboriginal culture
results.creator_credit: Link Films, Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Norma Disher
results.brief_description: The legends of Wayamba the turtle and Bohra the kangaroo retold by animated sketches based on the motifs of aboriginal bark paintings. An introductory sequence shows something of the variety and skill in aboriginal decorative art. Narrated by Leonard Teale.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting (A)
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Aboriginal art: conserving, exhibiting, interpreting
results.creator_credit: University of Sydney Television Service, Peter Lipscombe, David Roberts and Christoph Willing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Talking about Aboriginal art”.
In recent decades Aboriginal art has increasingly been destined for art museums and major private collections. It has not been totally subsumed into the Western art dealer and museum system, but has made curators and art historians ask some profound questions about their practices and policies of collecting and exhibiting art. One concern is the involvement of non- Aboriginal curators and art advisers, with many believing they occupy positions which would be more appropriately held by Aboriginal people. Curators Djon Mundine, Wally Caruana and Peter Sutton discuss gallery collecting policies, major exhibitions and key issues in the criticism of contemporary Aboriginal art.

results.title: Abnormal behavior: a mental hospital (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: CRM Productions, Tom Lazarus and Neil Reichline
results.brief_description: A series of doctor-patient interviews acquaint the viewer with the symptomatology of various types of schizophrenic disturbances. In an unusual sequence, a patient with paranoid tendencies is shown undergoing electro-convulsive therapy. The director of the hospital tells of the hospital’s goals in this and other forms of treatment.

results.title: Ablett: one special season
results.creator_credit: Australian Football Video, Dean Shiel and Stephen Phillips
results.brief_description: In one special season Gary Ablett redefined the way Australian Rules football’s rich history will judge him. Having set standards rarely matched by other players since his career began, Ablett’s 1993 was quite extraordinary - even for a man prone to producing the extraordinary. We follow Ablett’s path through the season, hear him speak on his performance and his place in the Geelong team and travel to Nauru with him as he umpires the local Grand Final. This is a fine tribute to one of the legends of the game.

results.title: Abilene Paradox (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: CRM Productions, Janice M Reynolds and Peter Jordon
results.brief_description: Deals with the management of agreement in organisations. Illustrates that mismanaged agreement is as dangerous to organisational effectiveness as excessive conflict because it can lead to inappropriate goals.
